g.text: appm helium-implanted tungsten studied here may be at the threshold dose for initating channeling, leading to
the observation of the weak, less well defined channels in Fig.
With regard to the channel morphology, we note that the channels in Fig.
to those observed in irradiated fcc metals for all damage levels
. With increasing dose, one may expect that
the straight slip channels in bcc tungsten will not only become wider, but also curved. For example in neutron
irradiated bcc vanadium, wide, river-pattern shaped channels have been observed with increasing dose from 0.12
. Bending of channels was also observed in neutron irradiated bcc iron for increasing dose from
. The high stacking fault energy (SFE) in bcc metals is expected to promote cross-slip of screw
, while in low SFE fcc metals, cross-slip is harder to initiate owing to the formation of partial dislo-
cations. Multiple cross-slip events per dislocation can help the formation of curved channels in bcc metals as each
cross-slip induces a sharp change in direction of the dislocation path
. Thus, the SFE may be considered respon-
sible for differences in the slip channel morphology between bcc and fcc metals, particularly at high doses
The proposed hypothesis for the interaction of glide dislocations with
V-SIA complexes was used to develop a user material (UMAT) for helium-implanted tungsten to allow
CPFE simulations of nano-indentation of this material. Details of the UMAT code are provided in Section 4.6.
Briefly, the UMAT uses a physically-based constitutive law governing the thermally activated glide of dislocations
through a field of pinning dislocations and He
V-SIA complexes. When the resolved shear stress on a given slip
is greater than the critically resolved shear stress
accounts for strain hardening using a Taylor hardening law
) accounts for the increased resistance to dislocation glide by the helium-implantation-induced
is the shear modulus of tungsten,
the initial critically resolved shear stress (CRSS
the GNDs produced on all slip-systems and
the proportion of GNDs considered contributing to hardening. For
helium-implanted tungsten i.e. removal of He
V-SIA complexes, is implemented by reducing
is the accumulated crystallographic slip and
the softening rate. The rate of decrease of
mated to be proportional to its current value i.e. the current helium-defect concentration
gesting the exponential softening rate in Eq. (
Only two UMAT parameters were fitted to the experimental result of the unimplanted sample;
These two are essential for simulating nano-indentation of pure tungsten
is fitted to the experimental result of the implanted sample. The
fitted load-displacement curves from CPFE are superimposed as dotted lines on the experimentally obtained
is computed as a function of the energy required for a gliding dislocation to dissociate helium from a
V-SIA complex and thus overcome this obstacle.
as such depends on the concentration of such defect com-
plexes, the size of an individual defect complex, the binding energy of the helium-vacancy complex and the
migration energy of the released interstitial helium at room temperature (details in Section 4.6.3). The
is a key novelty of the formulation, reducing the number of fitting parameters to only
MPa are applied to the helium-implanted layer to
account for the restricted in-plane displacement to maintain geometrical continuity between the implanted layer
and substrate (calculations in Appendix A in Supplementary Material)
. It is interesting to compare the CPFE
predicted load-displacement curves for the implanted material with and without these stress boundary condi-
tions, keeping all other UMAT parameters the same. The indentation load predicted without the residual stresses
is ~16% lower than the experimental observation. This implies that large residual stresses (here ~75% of
be accounted for in CPFE, to yield accurate predictions. Prior studies on hardness of mild steel, probed through
micro-indentation, showed a similar dependence on residual stress state
highlight that the impact of residual stress on indentation response continues to be important even at the
Surface morphology of indents: AfM vs cpfe.
The large increase in pile-up in the helium-implanted
material predicted by CPFE agrees very well with the surface height profile measured by AFM (Fig.
plots were made from AFM and CPFE contour plots in the
). From the line plots, ~172% increase in pile-up height
direction in the implanted sample. A relatively shallower residual indent impression in the
implanted sample is consistent with the observed increase in hardness.
Observations of maximum and minimum pile-up in the
slip directions in bcc tungsten. Dislocations gliding along any of the four
directions can exit where these directions intersect the sample surface (which here has [001] normal).
As such, the pile-up on the [001] plane, is expected to occur preferentially along the projection of the
directions on the [001] plane i.e. along the four
directions lying in the [001] plane which are at 90° to each
). Little pile-up is expected to occur along the
directions that lie in the [001] plane. We note
